title: NHS to roll out electronic prescriptions next month under plans to save £300million
text:

NHS prescriptions are to become digital from next month under plans to digitise the system and save the Government £300million.

Primary care minister, Jo Churchill, said the electronic prescription service (EPS) will be rolled out across England after a trial run in 60 GP practices and hundreds of pharmacies.

The Department of Health said it had received positive feedback from GPs and pharmacies on the back of the trial - with at least 70% of all prescriptions now being prescribed and dispensed through EPS.

The first EPS went live in 2009 at a GP surgery and pharmacy in Leeds. Once the final stage is rolled out, nearly all prescriptions will be sent electronically.

Under the system, patients can get their medications by either nominating a pharmacy that will receive the details directly from their GP or receive a paper prescription with the digital barcode.

Paper prescriptions will continue to be available for those who rely on them.

(Image: Getty Images)

The initiative will see medical information held on a secure NHS database called Spine which will allow a patient’s prescription to be accessed quickly by GPs and pharmacies.

The EPS is expected to save the NHS £300million by 2021 by increasing efficiencies, reducing the amount of paper processing and prescribing errors, the DHSC said.

Instead of using a physical signature patients will be allowed to digitally sign and cancel electronic prescriptions.

(Image: Getty)

The department said the system would reduce the amount of administration needed around prescriptions, and the volume of prescriptions that need to be stored.

"Digitising the entire prescription service is a key part of keeping up the drive to make the NHS fit for the 21st century. This will free up vital time for GPs and allow pharmacists to spend more time with their patients, and save millions of pounds a year," Jo Churchill said.

"It’s another important step towards eventually making all prescriptions paperless. We are continuing to improve technology across the NHS, which will ultimately improve care for patients."

Dr Ian Lowry, the director of digital medicines and pharmacy at NHS Digital, said: "Every prescription that is sent electronically saves money for the NHS by increasing efficiency. The system is also safer and more secure, as prescriptions can’t be lost and clinicians can check their status online.

"This is a huge milestone to reach, and one which benefits patients, GPs, pharmacists and the NHS as a whole."
description: A digital prescription service will be rolled out across England after a trial run in 60 GP practices and hundreds of pharmacies
